Graphical abstract Doping Mn at the heterointerfaces between Co3O4 and CeO2 enhances the selective catalytic reduction of NO by CO on the hollow Mn-doped Co3O4@CeO2 catalyst, showing approximately 82% NO conversion and 74% N2 selectivity at the temperature of 200 °C (5 vol% O2, 10 vol% H2O, 50 ppm SO2, and 24,000 h−1), much better than most reported catalysts. Selective catalytic reduction of NO using CO (CO-SCR) is a promising technology for the purification of NO in the flue gas. However, the presence of O2 significantly inhibits the activity of the CO-SCR catalyst. Herein, we synthesize a hollow Mn-doped CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst (Mn-CeO2@Co3O4), which achieved 82% NO conversion, 100% CO conversion, and 78% N2 selectivity under 5 vol% O2 at 200 °C, superior to those of CeO2@Co3O4 and Co3O4@CeO2 catalysts. The characterization results indicate that the strong electronic interaction at the heterointerfaces between Co3O4 and CeO2 plays a crucial role in promoting selective adsorption of NO. Furthermore, the Mn doping into the Co3O4 lattice of the catalyst facilitates the conversion of N2O intermediates, thereby enhancing the overall activity. This research provides a new strategy for the design and synthesis of CO-SCR catalysts. Keywords Hollow structure Heterointerface Mn doping CO-SCR O2-containing condition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Nitrogen oxides (NO x ), originating from the combustion of stationary and mobile sources of fuel, are major air pollutants that have significant implications for human health and the environment [1]. The selective catalytic reduction (SCR) is currently regarded as a promising denitrification technology due to its exceptional efficiency in removing NO x while minimizing secondary pollution [2,3]. Notably, the catalytic reduction of NO x using CO as a reducing agent (CO-SCR) allows for the direct utilization of CO in the flue gas, enabling economical and efficient NO x reduction [4]. Nevertheless, the O2 in the flue gas inhibits the denitrification effect, as CO and NO are preferentially oxidized by O2 [5]. Therefore, developing CO-SCR catalysts that can work under O2-containing conditions is an urgent and challenging task. At present, noble metal-based catalysts, such as Pt [6], Ir [7,8], Ag [9], and Rh [10], have shown good efficacy in promoting CO-SCR reactions. Nevertheless, their scarcity and exorbitant prices severely constrain their practical implementation. Consequently, researchers are seeking economical and efficient transition metal oxides as substitutes [11]. Among the transition metal oxides, Co3O4, MnO2, and CeO2 have emerged as promising candidate materials due to their high activity, low cost, and relatively good stability [12–14]. For instance, a nonstoichiometric CoO1- x with a rock-salt structure could achieve 100% N2 selectivity in temperatures of 250–520 °C in the CO-SCR reaction [15]. A MnO2/TiO2 catalyst showed more than 90% NO conversion at 200 °C [16]. Also, a CeO2-modified CuCoO2 catalyst exhibited a wide low-temperature activity window and 100% NO conversion at 175 °C [17]. Moreover, the structure and morphology of catalysts, including 2D flake [18], porous structure [19], and hollow structure [20], have been optimized to enhance their activity further. Additionally, defects such as impurity atom doping [21], vacancy [22], and amorphization [23] have been introduced to improve their intrinsic activity. Recently, hollow multi-shelled structure (HMSS) materials have gained significant attention in environmental treatment [24], lithium storage [25], drug delivery [26], and dye-sensitized solar cells [27] due to their unique properties such as low density, high permeability, and fast gas diffusion. In catalysis, this hollow structure provides a large surface area, increasing the effective contact between reactant molecules and active sites on the surface of catalysts, thereby enhancing catalytic activity. Furthermore, the multi-shelled structure can induce synergies influencing catalytic activity, selectivity, and structural stability due to interfacial interactions between the different components. For instance, HMSS CeO2-MnO x demonstrated 100% NO conversion in the temperature window of 150–200 °C for selective catalytic reduction of NO with NH3, much better than CeO2-MnO x nanoparticles [28]; HMSS Co3O4-CeO2- x achieved a full CO conversion at 166 °C and high stability without deactivation even after 100 h continuous operation in the CO oxidation reaction [29]. In addition, metal doping is another promising strategy to improve the catalytic functionality of denitrification. The atom doping of catalysts can create defects, modify the electronic structure, and increase the number of active sites [30]. For example, compared to the undoped Fe/CeO2, the Ni-doped Fe/CeO2 catalyst exhibited a significant increase in NO conversion from 42% to 92% in the presence of 0.5 vol% O2 because the doped Ni can provide extra CO adsorption sites in the CO-SCR reaction. Herein, we report a hard template method to synthesize hollow Mn-doped CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst (Mn-CeO2@Co3O4) with 82% NO conversion, full CO conversion, and 78% N2 selectivity at 200 °C in the CO-SCR reaction with 5 vol% O2. The spectroscopic characterization confirmed the formation of a hollow structure in the catalyst, with well-defined heterointerfaces between Co3O4 and CeO2. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) reveals that the heterointerfaces between Co3O4 and CeO2 exhibit strong electronic interactions, which are further enhanced by introducing Mn dopant. The in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (in situ DRIFTS) analysis proved that the Mn-doped CeO2@Co3O4 heterointerface facilitates the selective adsorption of NO as well as the formation and conversion of the key N2O intermediate in the CO-SCR reaction. This work reveals the role of Co3O4-CeO2 heterointerfaces in the CO-SCR process. 2 Experimental 2.1 Chemicals and materials Cobalt nitrate hexahydrate (Co(NO3)2·6H2O, AR, ≥99.5 wt%, Macklin Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd.), cerium nitrate hexahydrate (Ce(NO3)3·6H2O, AR, ≥99 wt%, Aladdin Industrial Co. Ltd.), manganese nitrate solution (Mn(NO3)2, 50% in H2O, Xilong Chemical Co. Ltd.), urea ((NH3)2CO3, AR, ≥99.8 wt%, Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co. Ltd.), sucrose (C12H22O11, AR, ≥99 wt%, Macklin Biochemical Technology Co. Ltd.), and deionized water were directly used for catalyst synthesis without further treatment. All gases, including 2 vol% CO/N2, 2 vol% NO/N2, O2 (≥99.99 vol%), and N2 (≥99.999 vol%), were purchased from Beijing Yongsheng Gas Technology Co. Ltd., China. 2.2 Preparation of catalysts Carbon Spheres (CSs): CSs were obtained by a hydrothermal method [31]. Typically, sucrose (0.058 mol, 20.00 g) was dissolved in distilled water (400 mL) and stirred with a magnetic stirrer. Then, the sucrose solution was transferred into a Teflon-lined autoclave of 500 mL capacity, sealed, and maintained at 200 °C for 5 h. After the reaction, the autoclave was cooled to room temperature naturally. The brown products were collected by centrifugation, washed with ethanol and distilled water several times, and dried at 60 °C for 12 h. Hollow CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst: CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst with a hollow structure is synthesized by a hard templating approach [32]. The CSs (0.022 mol, 0.26 g) were dispersed in 150 mL of Ce(NO3)3 (0.014 mol, 6.03 g) solution by ultrasonicating for 0.5 h and stirring for 0.5 h to ensure that Ce3+ ions can be sufficiently adsorbed on the surface of CSs. Then urea (0.25 mol, 15.00 g) was added, and the solution was stirred for 0.5 h. The obtained mixture was transferred into a flask, sealed, and maintained in a water bath at 90 °C for 8 h with continuous stirring. After that, the suspension was cooled to room temperature and centrifuged to obtain the Ce(OH)3@CSs. The Ce(OH)3@CSs precipitate was re-dispersed into the solution with the same concentration of Co(NO3)2 (0.014 mol, 4.04 g) by ultrasonicating for 0.5 h and stirring for 0.5 h, and urea (0.25 mol, 15.00 g) was added. The solution was kept stirring for 0.5 h. Afterward, the mixture was transferred into a flask, sealed, and maintained in a water bath at 90 °C for 8 h. The obtained precipitate was collected and washed several times with distilled water and ethanol, and then dried at 60 °C to get the Co(OH)2@Ce(OH)3@CSs precursor. The Co(OH)2@Ce(OH)3@CSs precursor was heated to 450 °C in air at the rate of 2 °C min−1, and kept at 450 °C for 4 h to remove the CSs template. Then, hollow CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst powder in gray color was collected after the furnace was cooled to room temperature. Hollow Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst: During the addition of Co(NO3)2 (0.014 mol, 4.04 g), Mn(NO3)3 (0.0002 mol, 0.073 g) aqueous solution was added at the same time, and other processes were same to the synthesis of hollow CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst, and the obtained catalyst was denoted as Mn-CeO2@Co3O4. Hollow CeO2, Co3O4, Co3O4@CeO2, MnO2-CeO2@Co3O4, and Mn-CeO2/Co3O4 as control samples were synthesized by the same method (details are given in Supporting Information). 2.3 Characterization The microscopic feature of the sample was observed by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (SEM) (JSM-7001F, JEOL, Tokyo, Japan) with energy-dispersive spectroscopy (EDS) (INCA X-MAX, JEOL, Oxford, England), and transmission electron microscopy (TEM) (JEM-2010F, 00JEOL, Tokyo, Japan). The surface chemical composition was determined by X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) (Model VG ESCALAB 250 spectrometer, Thermo Electron, U.K.) using a non-monochromatized Al Kα X-ray radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV). Textural characteristics of the samples were determined by a nitrogen adsorption operation at −196 °C on a Quantachrome NOVA-3200e adsorption analyzer by the Brunauer-Emmett-Teller (BET) method. Before analysis, the samples were preprocessed under vacuum at 300 °C for 4 h. The surface areas were calculated by the BET equation and the average pore diameter along with pore size distribution were determined by the equivalent cylindrical model analysis of Barrett-Joyner-Halenda (BJH) method. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed on an X-Ray diffractometer (PANalytica X’ Pert PRO MPD), and a Cu/Kα radiation was used as the resource (40 kV, 40 mA). The catalyst was scanned from 10 to 90° (2θ) at a 0.2 s/step. The crystallite sizes of all samples were calculated using the Debye-Scherrer equation. The reducibility of the samples was evaluated by the temperature-programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) on a Quanta Chrome Automated chemisorption analyzer (chemBET pulsar TPR/TPD). After loading 50 mg of the sample in a U-shaped quartz tube, the sample was heated to 150 °C in an Ar flow of 30 mL min−1, and flushed for 1 h at the same temperature. When the sample was cooled to 50 °C, 10 vol% H2 in Ar at a flow rate of 30 mL min−1 was switched. After stabilizing for about 30 min, the H2-TPR was performed from 50 to 1000 °C at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1. Thermal analyses (thermal gravimetric: TG) were carried out using a thermal analyzer (TG-DTA 6300, SII NanoTechnology Inc., Japan) with a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 up to 900 °C in an airflow (60 mL min−1). A Tensor 27 Fourier Transform–Infrared spectrophotometer (Bruker, Germany) was used to carry out FT–IR analyses. The in situ DRIFTS experiments were recorded using a Nicolet 380 FTIR equipped with an MCT detector. A resolution of 4 cm−1 and an accumulation of 32 scans were used for all the IR spectra. The samples were firstly pretreated in 100 mL min−1 N2 at 400 °C for 1 h. After that, the background spectra were collected at different temperatures before introducing the reacting gases. The DRIFTS experiments were conducted using the same gas mixture and space velocity as the catalytic activity test, and the spectra were collected simultaneously by raising the temperature from 50 °C to 400 °C. The catalysts were not treated prior to characterization. 2.4 Catalytic measurement The CO-SCR reaction was conducted in a fixed-bed quartz tubular reactor (inner diameter: 8 mm) with a thermocouple at its center. The catalysts were pretreated in a CO/N2 (2000 ppm CO and N2 as balance gas) gas flow at 200 °C for 1 h before each test. The catalytic activity of each 20–40 mesh catalyst (2.5 mL) was examined in the temperature range of 100–400 °C. The inlet gas comprised NO (1000 ppm), CO (2000 ppm), O2 (5 vol%), SO2 (50 ppm, in use), H2O (10 vol%, in use), and N2 (the balance). Gas hourly space velocity (GHSV) was fixed at 24,000 h−1. Regarding the analysis of exhaust, a multiple gas analyzer (Testo 350, Germany) was used to measure CO, NO, and NO2 concentrations. The N2O concentrations were analyzed using a portable composite gas analyzer (PTM600, Shenzhen Eranntex Electronics Co., LTD). NO conversion, CO conversion, and N2 selectivity were evaluated as follows: (1) X N O ( % ) = N O i n - N O o u t N O i n × 100 % (2) X C O ( % ) = C O i n - C O o u t C O i n × 100 % (3) S N 2 ( % ) = [ 1 - 2 N 2 O o u t + N O 2 o u t N O i n - N O o u t ] × 100 % where the “in” and “out” subscripts represent the inlet and outlet concentrations of NO and CO in the steady state, respectively. X NO and X CO are the NO and CO conversion, respectively; SN2 is the N2 selectivity. The reaction rate and activation energy (Ea) over the catalysts were measured at a gas flow rate of 1 L min−1 in the temperature range of 100–180 °C. To control X NO < 15%, the GHSVs of CeO2, Co3O4, CeO2@Co3O4, and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 were 40,000, 45,000, 55,000, and 60,000 h−1, respectively. The Ea was calculated using the Arrhenius equation. The specific reaction rate was evaluated by the following formula [33]: (4) R a t e ( m o l NO g - 1 cat h - 1 ) = F ( L m i n - 1 ) × C N O ( % ) 22.4 ( L m o l - 1 ) × X N O ( % ) m c a t ( g ) × 60 F is the total volume flow rate; CNO is the NO inlet volume fraction; mcat is the mass of catalyst. In addition, the turnover frequency (TOF) value per second was used to compare the intrinsic catalytic activity of the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst [34–37]. (5) T O F ( s - 1 ) = ν ( m 3 s - 1 ) × X N O V m ( m 3 m o l - 1 ) × n C o - s u r f . (6) n Co - surf . ( mol ) = N Co - su rf . N A ( mol - 1 ) where NCo-surf. is the number of Co atoms on the surfaces of catalysts and NA is the Avogadro constant (6.02 × 1023 mol−1). The calculation formulas for NCo-surf. were calculated as follows: (7) m ( g ) · S B E T ( m 2 g - 1 ) = S M n - s u r f . ( m 2 ) + S C o - s u r f . ( m 2 ) + S C e - s u r f . ( m 2 ) + S O - s u r f . ( m 2 ) = N M n - s u r f . · S M n - s i n g l e ( m 2 ) + N C o - s u r f . · S C o - s i n g l e ( m 2 ) + N C e - s u r f . · S C e - s i n g l e ( m 2 ) + N O - s u r f . · S O - s i n g l e ( m 2 ) where m is the mass of catalysts used for XPS analysis (0.2 g); SBET is the surface area of catalysts (Table 1 ); and SMn-single, SCo-single, SCe-single, and SO-single are the surface areas of single atoms, which were estimated by the hemispheric surface area (2πr2). The atomic radii employed for Mn, Co, Ce, and O are as follows [38,39]: rMn = 1.24 × 10-10 m, rCo = 1.253 × 10-10 m, rCe = 1.65 × 10-10 m, and rO = 6.4 × 10-11 m. The relationship between NMn-surf., NMn-surf., and NMn-surf. was calculated based on the XPS analysis results, relevant values are listed in Table 3 . 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of the catalysts 3.1.1 SEM and TEM observations Fig. 1 shows the SEM images of the CeO2@Co3O4 and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 samples. Uniform carbon spheres with a diameter of about 1.8 µm are observed in Fig. S1a. Among the three samples, CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. 1a), Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. 1b), and Co3O4@CeO2 (Fig. S1b), consist of spherical particles with an approximate diameter of 4 µm. Meanwhile, the elemental mapping analyses in Fig. 1c, 1d, and S1c suggest that the synthesized samples own a hollow sphere structure. O, Ce, and Co elements are uniformly distributed in Co3O4@CeO2 (Fig. S1c) and CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. 1c) samples while O, Ce, Co, and Mn elements are uniformly distributed in the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. 1d) sample. For CeO2@Co3O4 and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 samples, the Ce element is mainly confined to the inter shell region while Co element is homogeneously distributed in the outer shell. The innermost diameters of CeO2@Co3O4 and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 samples are almost the same (3.5 μm). In contrast, for Co3O4@CeO2 sample, the Co element is primarily confined to the inner shell, while Ce element is uniformly distributed in the outer shell. It is worth noting that the diameter of the inner shell of the Co3O4@CeO2 sample (2 μm) is significantly smaller than that of CeO2@Co3O4 and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 samples, implying that the inner shell and outer shell in the Co3O4@CeO2 sample is separated. Additionally, the EDS analysis further confirms the element composition of Co3O4@CeO2 (Fig. S2a), CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. S2b), and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. S2c), and the Mn/Co atomic ratio in Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 sample is 0.013:1 (Table 1). The TEM images reveal the formation of hollow structure in the Co3O4@CeO2 (Fig. S3a), CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. 2 a), and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. 2b) samples. Notably, an intimate interfacial region exists between two shell layers in the CeO2@Co3O4 and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 samples. In contrast, the Co3O4@CeO2 sample exhibits clear gaps between the two shells. On the outer shell, the lattice distances of 0.31 and 0.19 nm corresponded to the (111) and (220) planes of CeO2, respectively, in Co3O4@CeO2 (Fig. S3b). For CeO2@Co3O4, the measured inter-planar lattice distances of 0.23 and 0.28 nm corresponded to the (222) and (220) planes of Co3O4, respectively (Fig. 2c). Moreover, Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. 2d) exhibits the lattice distances of 0.23 and 0.28 nm corresponded to the (222) and (220) planes of Co3O4, respectively. No lattice corresponding to Mn species was observed, implying that Mn was inserted into the Co3O4 lattice. 3.1.2 XRD analysis The XRD patterns of all samples with hollow structures are shown in Fig. S4a and 3a. The observed diffraction peaks at 2θ values of 28.7°, 33.2°, 47.7°, 56.6°, 59.3°, 69.7°, 77.0°, 79.5°, and 88.9° are indexed to the characteristic peaks of CeO2 (JCPDS No. 075–0076), corresponding to the (111), (200), (220), (311), (222), (400), (331), (420), and (422) planes, respectively. The diffraction peaks located at 2θ values of 19.0°, 31.4°, 36.9°, 38.6°, 44.9°, 59.5°, and 65.4° are assigned to the (111), (220), (311), (222), (400), (511), and (440) planes of cubic-phased Co3O4 (JCPDS No. 071–0816), respectively. As shown in Fig. S4a, Co3O4@CeO2 showed similar diffraction peaks as CeO2, and a slight peak shift is observed over CeO2@Co3O4 sample. The ionic radius of Co ions (Co2+ = 0.72 Å, Co3+ = 0.645 Å) is smaller than that of Ce ions (Ce4+ = 1.01 Å, Ce3+ = 0.87 Å). Therefore, Co ions could be incorporated into the lattice of CeO2 to form the CeO2-Co3O4 heterointerfaces [14,40]. Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 showed similar but slightly shifted and stronger diffraction peaks than CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. 3 b), indicating that the Mn ions were incorporated into the Co3O4 lattice [21]. It is also noticed that introducing Mn into the Co3O4 decreases the grain size of Co3O4, agreeing with the above TEM analysis. 3.1.3 N2 adsorption measurements Fig. 4 a displays the N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms of CeO2, Co3O4, CeO2@Co3O4, and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 samples. The samples of CeO2, Co3O4, Co3O4@CeO, and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 in Fig. 4a, as well as Co3O4@CeO2 in Fig. S5, exhibited type IV adsorption isotherm. The hysteresis loop in a relative pressure (P/P0) range between 0.5 and 1 illustrates the presence of irregular mesopores from stacking particles [40]. The CeO2 and Co3O4 catalysts exhibited surface areas of 33.5 and 35.7 m2 g−1, respectively. With the formation of the double-shell structure, the surface areas of CeO2@Co3O4, Mn-CeO2@Co3O4, and Co3O4@CeO2 increased to 51.4, 66.3, and 64.1 m2 g−1, respectively (Table 1 and S1). The corresponding BJH pore size distribution (Fig. 4b) shows that CeO2, Co3O4, CeO2@Co3O4, and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 had a wide peak scattering from 5 to 50 nm. Three samples show almost identical surface areas and pore structure, as summarized in Table 1 and S1. 3.1.4 H2-TPR analysis Fig. 5 and S6 show the H2-TPR results of the CeO2, Co3O4, CeO2@Co3O4, Mn-CeO2@Co3O4, and Co3O4@CeO2 samples. The CeO2 sample presented two reduction peaks (545 and 820 °C), corresponding to the surface oxygens of nonstoichiometric cerium and bulk oxygen in CeO2, respectively [24]. For the Co3O4 sample, the two reduction peaks correspond to the two reduction steps of Co3O4, which are the reduction from Co3O4 to CoO (413 °C) and from CoO to Co (474 °C) [41]. The reduction peaks of Co3O4@CeO2, CeO2@Co3O4, and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 samples are deconvoluted into three peaks. In the case of the CeO2@Co3O4 sample, three reduction peaks centered at 398 (I), 465 (II), and 820 °C (III). Peak I is attributed to the reduction of surface oxygen species. Peak II can be mainly attributed to the reduction of Co3+ at the interface between Co3O4 and CeO2 to Co2+ because Co3O4 has higher reducibility compared to CeO2 [42]. Peak III corresponds to the reduction of bulk CeO2 [43]. In addition, three samples (CeO2@Co3O4, Mn-CeO2@Co3O4, and Co3O4@CeO2) exhibit similar reduction peaks and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 shows the lowest reduction temperatures. Introducing Mn in Co3O4 affected the surface electronic structure of the CeO2@Co3O4 sample, thus lowering the temperature of the reduction peaks [21]. Furthermore, the H2 consumption of Co3O4@CeO2 is greater than that of CeO2@Co3O4 and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 (Table 2 and S2), indicating that CeO2@Co3O4 and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 possess more oxygen vacancies (OVs). In short, the observed lower reduction peaks of Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 compared to those of CeO2@Co3O4 indicate that a strong interaction between Mn, Co3O4, and CeO2 enhances the redox ability of the sample. 3.1.5 XPS analysis As shown in Fig S7, the XPS spectra of CeO2@Co3O4 and Co3O4@CeO2 samples reveal the presence of Co, Ce, and O. Additionally, the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 sample confirms the presence of Mn, Co, Ce, and O, consistent with the EDS mapping results (Fig. 1c, 1d, and S2). The binding energies of Mn, Co, Ce, and O elements were corrected using the C 1s peak at 284.8 eV as a reference. In Fig. 6 a and S8a, the Ce 3d XPS spectrum displays six main peaks at 882.46, 888.90, 897.98, 898.67, 907.34, and 916.60 eV, corresponding to the characteristic v, v″, v″′, u, u″, and u″′ modes of the Ce4+ state; the peaks v′ at 885.39 eV and u′ at 901.21 eV can be attributed to the Ce3+ state [44]. Furthermore, compared to Co3O4@CeO2, the binding energy of Ce 3d peaks in CeO2@Co3O4 sample shifts to higher values, which can be attributed to the interfacial charge transfer from Co3O4 to CeO2. The Mn-CeO2@Co3O4, as shown in Table 3, exhibits a higher ratio of Ce3+/Ce4++Ce3+ (21.1%) compared to CeO2@Co3O4 (19.7%). This variation valence state of Ce is induced by Mn, which facilitates electron transfer between two phases. According to the calculations based on peak fitting area, the surface Ce atomic concentration is lower for CeO2@Co3O4 (5.3%) and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 (3.9%) compared to Co3O4@CeO2 (22.9%), as summarized in Table 3 and S3. The results suggest that a close contact interface was formed between Co3O4 and CeO2, consistent with the TEM analysis (Fig. 2a, 2b, and S3). The Co 2p spectra of CeO2@Co3O4 and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 are shown in Fig. 6b, the peaks labeled as u, v, uo, and vo correspond to Co2+ 2p1/2, Co2+ 2p3/2, Co3+ 2p1/2, and Co3+ 2p3/2, respectively, indicating the presence of both Co2+ and Co3+ species [45]. Notably, the peaks of Co 2p in Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 shift to lower binding energy compared to CeO2@Co3O4. This shift can be attributed to Mn, which possesses a lower electronegativity (1.55) than Co (1.88). Consequently, significant charge transfer occurs between Mn and Co species [46]. As summarized in Table 3, the Co2+/Co3+ ratio of the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 was greater than that of CeO2@Co3O4, suggesting a higher concentration of OVs on the surface of Mn-CeO2@Co3O4. For Co3O4@CeO2, the Co 2p spectrum is not observed due to the coating of the CeO2 shell (Fig. S8b). In Fig. 6c, the Mn 2p3/2 spectrum is fitted with three characteristic peaks, which are attributed to Mn2+ (640.8 eV), Mn3+ (642.5 eV), and Mn4+ (644.2 eV), respectively [47]. In addition, the O 1s spectra of all samples (Fig. 6d and S8c) exhibit two distinct peaks. The peak binding energy at 529.7 eV corresponds to lattice oxygen (referred to as O β ), while the peak at 531.4 eV corresponds to chemisorbed oxygen O2 2– or defect oxygen (referred to as O α ). Clearly, we observe a significantly higher O α content on CeO2@Co3O4 and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 compared to Co3O4@CeO2, suggesting that CeO2@Co3O4 and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 own abundant OVs. The XPS survey spectrum (Fig. S9) indicates the presence of Mn, Co, Ce, and O. The XPS results for the MnO2-CeO2@Co3O4 sample are shown in Fig. S10. In the local enlarged view of the Co 2p spectrum (Fig. S10c), compared to the CeO2@Co3O4 sample, the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 and MnO2-CeO2@Co3O4 samples shift 0.9 eV and 0.3 eV towards lower binding energies, respectively. These observations suggest the presence of electronic transfer between Mn and Co species. However, a slight shift towards a lower energy position after Mn doping may be attributed to the interfacial charge transfer between Mn and Co3O4. 3.2 The formation of the hollow Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst The hollow Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst was prepared through a three-step method using CSs as a sacrificial template. The synthesis process is illustrated in Scheme 1 . In the first step, core–shell CSs@Ce(OH)3 particles were formed by the hard template method. This involves depositing Ce species uniformly onto the surface of the CSs. The negatively charged surface functional groups of the CSs, such as hydroxyl or carboxylic acid, facilitate the adsorption of Ce ions from a Ce(NO3)3·6H2O solution [48]. Urea was then added to the solution and hydrolyzed upon heating at 90 °C, releasing OH− ions. These OH− ions reacted with Ce ions to generate Ce(OH)3. In the second step, the as-prepared CSs@Ce(OH)3 precursor particles were mixed to an aqueous solution of Co(NO3)2·6H2O, forming yolk-shell CSs@Co(OH)2/Ce(OH)3 particles. Similarly, adding Mn(NO3)2 solution to the Co(NO3)2·6H2O aqueous solution formed CSs@Mn-Co(OH)2/Ce(OH)3 composite particles. In the third step, the thermal decomposition process of the CSs@Mn-Co(OH)2/Ce(OH)3 precursors was studied by TG to monitor the conversion process from CSs@Mn-Co(OH)2/Ce(OH)3 to Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 and determine the proper temperature for the removal of CSs (Fig. S11). The well-defined hollow structure Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 was obtained by annealing the as-prepared CSs@Mn-CeO2/Co3O4 spheres, which were confirmed by EDS, SEM, and TEM spectra (Figs. S2, 3a, and S7). 3.3 Catalytic performances of the catalysts The catalytic performance of all the catalysts for the CO-SCR reaction with 5 vol% O2 was evaluated within the temperature range of 100–400 °C. In Fig. 7 a, the CeO2@Co3O4 and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalysts showed much higher activity than the CeO2 and Co3O4 catalysts. The NO conversion over CeO2@Co3O4 reached 74% at 200 °C, while the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 exhibited an even higher NO conversion of 82%. Meanwhile, the CO conversion reached 100% on all the catalysts in Fig. 7b. It is worth noting that the N2 selectivity of all the catalysts at 200 °C followed the order of Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 (78%) > CeO2@Co3O4 (21%) > CeO2 (16%) > Co3O4 (15%), as indicated in Fig. 7c. While N2 selectivity remains constant, NO2 selectivity decreases as temperature rises from 100 to 400 °C (Fig. S12). Concentrations of N2O mostly fell within the the detection limit range of the instrument (±10 ppm) [12]. In all, doping Mn significantly enhances the catalytic activity and selectivity. Additionally, the catalytic activity of Co3O4@CeO2 was examined within the temperature range of 100–400 °C in Fig. S13a-S13c. It was found that the Co3O4@CeO2 catalyst exhibited lower NO conversion and N2 selectivity than CeO2@Co3O4 and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 under the identical reaction conditions. As shown in Table 4 , the calculated TOF of the NO reduction over the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst was 0.49 s−1 at 120 °C, superior to that of the most reported catalysts in the literature. Furthermore, the catalyst was further tested at different temperatures starting from high to low, as shown in Fig. S14, which also retains stable catalytic properties. To confirm the role of Mn doping in the reaction, we prepared the MnO2-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst and measured its NO conversion (Fig. S15a), CO conversion (Fig. S15b), and N2 selectivity (Fig. S15c) under the same reaction conditions. MnO2-CeO2@Co3O4 shows much lower catalytic performance than the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4, confirming the significance of Mn doping at the heterointerfaces of Co3O4 and CeO2 in CO-SCR. The catalytic performance of Mn-CeO2/Co3O4 was also investigated (Fig. S16). Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 demonstrates superior catalytic activity compared to Mn-CeO2/Co3O4, attributed to the hollow structure of the former. Moreover, the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst showed good stability with 71% NO conversion during a continuous test for 120 h at 200 °C (Fig. S17). To further confirm the validity and reliability of the catalytic data, we conducted three repeated experiments under the same conditions, testing the NO conversion, CO conversion, and N2 selectivity of the optimal Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst (Fig. S18a-S18c). Fig. 7d-7f show the effect of H2O and SO2 on the CeO2@Co3O4 and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalysts at 200 °C. Meanwhile, the effect of H2O and SO2 on Co3O4@CeO2 catalyst (Fig. S13d-13f) was tested at the optimized operating temperature of 300 °C. After introducing SO2 (50 ppm) for 90 min, the NO conversion on Co3O4@CeO2, CeO2@Co3O4, and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalysts dropped to 50%, 52%, and 68%, respectively, in Fig. 7d and S13d. When SO2 are switched off, the NO conversion on Co3O4@CeO2, CeO2@Co3O4, and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 recover to 53%, 68%, and 78%, respectively. Furthermore, the impact of H2O was investigated in Fig. S13e and 7e. Introducing 10 vol% H2O significantly reduced the NO conversion, reaching 46%, 58%, and 65% for Co3O4@CeO2, CeO2@Co3O4, and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4, respectively. The decreased NO conversion could be attributed to the competitive adsorption of NO and H2O. Additionally, the combined effect of H2O and SO2 in the CO-SCR reduction was investigated (Fig. S13f and 7f). When H2O and SO2 were present simultaneously, the NO conversion on Co3O4@CeO2, CeO2@Co3O4, and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 dropped to 38%, 48%, and 55%, respectively. Nevertheless, when H2O and SO2 were switched off, the NO conversion on Co3O4@CeO2, CeO2@Co3O4, and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 recover to 53%, 63%, and 70%, respectively, highlighting the good SO2 and H2O resistance of the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst compared to CeO2@Co3O4. However, the performance of the Co3O4@CeO2 catalyst was notably inferior compared to that of the other two catalysts. The enhanced SO2 and H2O resistance of CeO2@Co3O4 and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 can be attributed to the protective effect of the Co3O4 shell, which effectively mitigates the catalyst deactivation. Importantly, adding a specific quantity of Mn into the CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst significantly enhances the resistance of the catalyst to SO2 and H2O and its overall performance in the CO-SCR reaction. In addition, the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst demonstrated superior catalytic performance compared to most catalysts reported in the literature (Table 4). The FT-IR spectra of the used catalysts (Fig. S19a) were analyzed after exposure to flue gas containing SO2 and/or H2O. The presence of SO2 led to the formation of sulfites, as indicated by infrared absorptions at 626 cm−1 [41]. However, the vibration absorptions were absent in the used catalysts after SO2 and/or H2O poisoning tests (Fig. S19b), suggesting that the catalytic performance decreased with SO2 and did not fully recover upon its removal. It was found that SO2 permanently occupied the surface active sites as sulfates, leading to a decrease in catalyst performance [49]. Additionally, a portion of the introduced SO2 weakly adsorbed on the catalyst surface, further impairing its performance. However, with extended reaction time at 200 °C, these species desorbed from the catalyst surface, resulting in partial recovery of performance. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherms demonstrated structural damage to the catalysts caused by SO2 and/or H2O poisoning, with decreased specific surface area and alterations in pore size distribution (Fig. S20a and S20b). XRD analysis (Fig. S20c) showed that the crystal structures of the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst remained largely unchanged after the poisoning test, indicating no severe structural collapse. Additional control experiments were conducted to evaluate the catalytic performance of the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst with and without CO pretreatment (Fig. S21). The Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst subjected to CO pretreatment exhibited superior performance, achieving a NO conversion of 82% at 200 °C, while the untreated catalyst showed a NO conversion of 75 at 250 °C in the CO-SCR reaction. CO pretreatment can effectively remove surface oxides and impurities from the catalyst. Additionally, CO pretreatment enhances the formation and distribution of OVs and provides more active sites for the NO and CO reaction in the catalyst, thus leading to improved catalytic performance. Furthermore, the specific reaction rates and apparent activation energies (Ea) are calculated to compare the intrinsic activities of CeO2, Co3O4, Mn-CeO2@Co3O4, CeO2@Co3O4, and Co3O4@CeO2 catalysts. Kinetic performance tests were conducted on NO conversion below 10% to exclude mass and heat transfer effects, using the Arrhenius equation [36,49]. The results (Fig. 8 and S23) show that Mn-CeO2@Co3O4, Co3O4@CeO2, and CeO2@Co3O4 catalysts exhibit higher specific reaction rates compared to CeO2 and Co3O4 catalysts in the temperature range of 100 to 180 °C. Notably, the specific reaction rate over Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 is highest (1.98 mol−1 NO g−1 cat h−1) in Fig. 8a, about 2 and 4 times higher than that over CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst (0.97 mol−1 NO g−1 cat h−1) and Co3O4@CeO2 catalyst (0.35 mol−1 NO g−1 cat h−1) in Fig. S23a. The measured E a values for CeO2, Co3O4, CeO2@Co3O4, and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 in Fig. 8b and Co3O4@CeO2 in Fig. S23b are 40.40, 40.24, 32.75, 24.36, and 39.70 kJ mol−1, respectively. Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 has the lowest E a value, suggesting that CO-SCR on this catalyst has the lowest activation barrier. 3.4 Proposed reaction mechanism 3.4.1 In situ DRIFTS measurements of NO adsorption The in situ DRIFTS spectra of NO + O2 adsorption were recorded on Co3O4@CeO2 (Fig. S24a), CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. 9 a), and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. 9b). The peaks of gaseous NO at 1845 and 1905 cm−1 can be observed. The bands at 1758 and 1631 cm−1 are ascribed to the adsorption of N2O2 and antisymmetric stretching vibration of bridge bidentate NO3 − species, respectively [39,41,46]. Furthermore, the peak intensity at 1758 cm−1 gradually increases with temperature, and the N2O2 adsorption peak intensity on Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 is stronger than that on Co3O4@CeO2 and CeO2@Co3O4. The gaseous NO on the catalyst surface also undergoes significant changes, and the peaks at 1845 and 1905 cm−1 disappear with increasing temperature. Additionally, as indicated in Fig. 9a and 9b, the vibration peaks of N2O at 2082 cm−1 were detected. 3.4.2 In situ DRIFTS measurements of CO adsorption In situ DRIFTS spectra of CO adsorbed on the Co3O4@CeO2 (Fig. S24b), CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. 10 a), and Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. 10b) catalysts surface were tested as the temperature increased from 50 to 400 °C. For all the samples, the peaks associated with gaseous CO arise at 2117 and 2174 cm−1, and they belong to the characteristic peaks of Co2+–CO and Ce3+–CO [61]. The bands observed at 2300–2400 cm−1 are the characteristic vibrations of gaseous CO2, implying that CO reacted with catalyst surface-active oxygen species to CO2 [62]. With increasing temperature, a red-shift was observed in the asymmetric stretching vibration peak of the carbonyl group, gradually from 1623 cm−1 to 1572 cm−1, which is attributed to the poor thermal stability of the substance [63]. Additionally, the peak at 1265 cm−1, attributed to monodentate carbonate CO3 2−, blue-shifted to 1301 cm−1 [64]. The peaks at 1486 and 1036 cm−1 correspond to surface carbonate and the v(C-O) vibration, respectively [65]. The more distinct characteristic peaks indicate more diverse carbonate species. Moreover, these peaks gradually intensified as the temperature increased. Notably, after reaching 200 °C, a significant increase in carbonate species was observed. 3.4.3 In situ DRIFTS measurements of NO and CO co-adsorption The in situ DRIFTS spectra were employed to examine the co-adsorption of CO and NO on the catalysts at increasing temperatures, as shown in Fig. 11 and S24c. Both CO and NO were adsorbed on sites similar to those observed in separate adsorption experiments (Fig. 9, 10, S24a, and S24b). The frequency band corresponding to the vibration mode of M-(NO)2 was observed at 1758 cm−1, and its intensity gradually decreased in the Co3O4@CeO2 (Fig. S24c) and CeO2@Co3O4 (Fig. 11a) catalysts. The peak associated with M-(NO)2 was nearly absent in the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst (Fig. 11b). Additionally, significant decreases in the peaks at 2174 and 2117 cm−1 were detected for CO, indicating its reactivity with the intermediate species. Notably, the N2O generated during individual NO adsorption experiments at 2082 cm−1 disappeared, indicating the N2O is the intermediate in the CO-SCR reaction. In addition, the intermediates formed by the CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst are essentially the same as those formed by Mn-CeO2@Co3O4, indicating that they have the same reaction route. Moreover, in the Co3O4@CeO2 and CeO2@Co3O4 catalysts, the intensity of the peak at 1905 cm−1 increased significantly with increasing temperature. For the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst, the peak at 1905 cm−1 appeared at 200 °C, indicating that higher temperatures result in a higher percentage of CO combining with surface active oxygen to form CO2. Upon co-adsorption of CO and NO, the peak intensities corresponding to the adsorbed species of CO and NO decreased significantly compared to the in situ DRIFTS spectra of individual CO and NO adsorption. This decrease confirms the occurrence of reactions between CO and the adsorbed N2O, consistent with the aforementioned observations. 3.4.4 Possible mechanism for the CO–SCR reaction over the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst Based on the in situ DRIFTS measurements and kinetic experiments (Fig. S25 and S26), we propose a possible reaction mechanism for the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst in the CO-SCR reaction, as shown in Fig. 12 . In this mechanism, different species and interfaces are represented as gas-phase species (g), surface sites (*), the interface of Co3O4 and CeO2 with OVs (Mn-Co–□-Ce), and the interface of Co3O4 and CeO2 without OVs (Mn-Co-O-Ce). First, NO adsorbs on the catalyst surface, forming adsorbed NO species (Eq. (1)). This step is the rate-determining step in the CO-SCR reaction, which is based on the above kinetic tests analysis (Fig. S26). Then, as the reaction temperature increases, some of the adsorbed NO reacts with OVs on the surface of catalysts (Eq. (2)). The reaction of gaseous CO with Mn-Co-O-Ce + N* results in the formation of adsorbed CO species (Eq. (3)). The bridge oxygen of Mn-Co-O-Ce species reacts with adsorbed CO to generate Mn-Co–□-Ce and gaseous CO2 (Eq. (4)). Subsequently, the adsorbed NO reacts with N* to N2O* (Eq. (5)). N2O* is further dissociated on Mn-CO–□-Ce to O* and N2 (Eq. (6)). Finally, the elementary reaction expressed in Eq. (7) is the second CO molecule that reacts with O* to produce a second CO2 and regenerates OVs to complete the entire redox reaction cycle. Compared to the Co3O4@CeO2 and CeO2@Co3O4 catalysts, the Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst contains more OVs (based on XPS and H2-TPR results), which promotes NO adsorption and improves the reactivity of CO-SCR. (1) NO(g) + * → NO* (2) Mn-Co-□-Ce + NO* → Mn-Co-O-Ce + N* (3) Mn-Co-O-Ce + N* +CO(g) + * → Mn-Co-O-Ce + N* + CO* (4) Mn-Co-O-Ce + N* + CO* → Mn-Co-□-Ce + N* + CO2(g) + * (5) N* + NO(g)→N2O* (6) N 2 O * → N 2 ( g ) + O * (7) O * + C O ( g ) → C O 2 ( g ) + * 4 Conclusions In summary, a hollow Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst was successfully synthesized using a hard template method. The spectroscopy analysis confirmed the hollow structure and heterogeneous interface between Co3O4 and CeO2 in the catalysts. Mn doping in the CeO2@Co3O4 created additional active sites and modulated the electronic structure of the catalyst. The Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst exhibited 82% NO conversion, 100% CO conversion, and 78% N2 selectivity at 200 °C under 5 vol% O2, surpassing the performance of CeO2@Co3O4 and Co3O4@CeO2 catalysts. Combined with XPS, H2-TPR, and in situ DRIFTS, results suggest that the excellent performances are attributed to the synergistic effects and surface-active species in the hollow Mn-CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst. This work would provide a promising path for efficient CO-SCR catalyst design based on the promotion effect of heterointerfaces, especially under O2-containing conditions. coredata.dc:description: Selective catalytic reduction of NO using CO (CO-SCR) is a promising technology for the purification of NO in the flue gas. However, the presence of O2 significantly inhibits the activity of the CO-SCR catalyst. Herein, we synthesize a hollow Mn-doped CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst (Mn-CeO2@Co3O4), which achieved 82% NO conversion, 100% CO conversion, and 78% N2 selectivity under 5 vol% O2 at 200 °C, superior to those of CeO2@Co3O4 and Co3O4@CeO2 catalysts. The characterization results indicate that the strong electronic interaction at the heterointerfaces between Co3O4 and CeO2 plays a crucial role in promoting selective adsorption of NO. Furthermore, the Mn doping into the Co3O4 lattice of the catalyst facilitates the conversion of N2O intermediates, thereby enhancing the overall activity. This research provides a new strategy for the design and synthesis of CO-SCR catalysts.
coredata.dc:title: Hollow Mn-doped CeO2@Co3O4 catalyst for NO reduction by CO
